citeinfo.title: Shark River Site 4 SET Data (ver 2.0, July 2019)

descript.abstract: This data set represents sediment elevation table data from the Shark River site 4 in Everglades National Park. Nine SETs study sites are located near U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) hydrological stations in Everglades National Park. The coupling of coastal sediment elevation with Hydrology data is important aid in evaluating sea level changes influences to coastal ground elevations. The basic concept of the SET is a fixed reference point either local surveyed or tied to a known vertical datum is used to evaluate sediment change over time. Sediment change can occur from physical and biological factors, which through erosion or accretion raise or lower the sediment profile. There are three modified SET designs used by the USGS in the Everglades (Original, Shallow and Deep). However, all are based on the SET design, consisting of a mechanical arm with a measurement plate at the end, which is pivoted out from the fixed reference point and leveled. The cantilevered mechanical arm radiates out from the fixed reference point in a circle to a determined bearing (typically the reference SET point is measured at four bearings) where a sediment measurement can be sampled. The measurement plate (or bar) has a series of machined holes (typically nine) through the plate, allowing fiberglass rods (also referred to as pins) to be inserted and lower through the plate to the ground surface. Each fiberglass rod is gently lowered through the plate hole until the rod tip touches the ground surface. The rod segment above plate is measured and the change in ground surface elevation is determined by subtracting the known rod length from the above rod segment length (i.e.: more rod segment above the plate is indicative of increased sediment. At each SET four fixed bearing measurements, nine measuring pins are lowered to the soil surface to obtain a relative soil elevation.
descript.purpose: Sediment Elevation Tables or SETs are used to measure rates of surface sediment elevation change due to soil accretion or erosion in the coastal mangrove, and marshes of the Everglades. Soil surface elevation is an important response variable in wetland environments.

cntperp.cntorg: Wetland and Aquatic Research Center, Wetland and Forested Ecosystems Branch

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

procstep.procdesc: Each SET consists of a mechanical arm with a measurement plate at the end, which is pivoted out from the fixed reference point and leveled. The cantilevered mechanical arm radiates out from the fixed reference point in a circle to a determined bearing (typically the reference SET point is measured at four bearings) where a sediment measurement can be sampled. The measurement plate (or bar) has a series of machined holes (typically nine) through the plate, allowing fiberglass rods (also referred to as pins) to be inserted and lower through the plate to the ground surface. Each fiberglass rod is gently lowered through the plate hole until the rod tip touches the ground surface. The height of each rod above the measurement plate is measured to the nearest millimeter.

Version History for Everglades National Park sediment elevation and marker horizon data release
Feher, L.C., Osland, M.J., and Anderson, G.H., 2019, Everglades National Park sediment elevation and marker horizon data release (ver 2.0, July 2019): U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F7348HNP.
________________________________________________________
Original posted online August 10, 2017 ________________________________________________________
Version 2.0 revised and reposted online July 2019
Changes in version 2.0
1. Added several additional columns of sediment elevation and marker horizon data from sampling events from the period between September 2014 and April 2019. 2. Revised the SET pin height values collected prior to April 2019 to reflect the length of new fiberglass pins. Note that in some instances this conversion resulted in negative pin height values. 3. Added data from new marker horizon plots that were installed during the May 2017 or December 2018 sampling events. ________________________________________________________

attr.attrdef: Compass azimuth from SET benchmark in which the measurement was made
SET pin height reading by date.

edom.edomvd: No reading - designated when the SET was not measured on a specific date
Hole - designated when a measurement was not taken because there was no clear bottom position for reading
Debris - designated when a measurement was not taken because a large piece of wood or vegetative matter that could not easily be pushed aside obscured the soil surface

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
